Subjective: Fatigue, 2 months duration. Wakes up tired despite sleeping a lot. Sleep sometimes superficial. No clear precipitating event. Gradual onset unclear. Work ongoing, but with significant effort; considered calling in sick. Weekends spent resting/catching up on sleep. Sports (climbing, cycling) possible, no significant loss of strength or endurance. Some increased muscle pain, more than usual. Back pain, more than usual. Googled symptoms, considered rheumatism due to morning stiffness. Father had back problems. No specific joint pain in hands/feet. No snoring, but occasional startling awakenings (lifelong, ~1x/week). Hay fever symptoms controlled with medication. No palpitations, chest pain. Appetite normal. Weight stable (72kg). Bowel movements normal, several times daily. Urination normal. Request: Wants blood tests to investigate cause of fatigue and muscle pain, rule out rheumatism/anemia/thyroid issues.
Objective: Vitals: BP 110/60, HR 40-50 (athletic bradycardia). Lungs: Clear. Back: Mild tenderness next to midline on palpation. Pelvis: No pain on lateral compression. Paraspinal muscles: Feels good, no left/right difference. Neck: Full ROM, no pain. Abdomen: Bowel sounds active, tympanic to percussion, supple, no tenderness on palpation.
Assessment: Fatigue, unspecified cause. Rule out: Anemia, hypothyroidism, inflammatory arthritis (rheumatoid arthritis), cardiac/pulmonary pathology. Musculoskeletal pain, likely secondary to fatigue/deconditioning.
Plan:
- Blood tests: CBC (anemia), TSH (thyroid), ESR/CRP (inflammation).
- Patient to receive lab form via inbox, schedule appointment at Atal Medial.
- Call day after testing for results and to schedule phone appointment.
- Discussed possibility of rheumatism, but physical exam and history less suggestive.
- Reassurance regarding BP and HR.
- Safety netting: Call if worsening fatigue, new symptoms (shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, significant weakness), or concerning lab results.
